commit_list.message:
[GUILT PATCH 3/5] guilt-select: Select guards to apply when pushing patches

guilt-select chooses guards that alter which patches will be applied
with a guilt-push.  The selected guards are stored in
.git/patches/$branch/guards.

[jeffpc: small tweak of the usage string]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>
commit_list.repo_description: My patches on upstream guilt http://repo.or.cz/guilt.git

commit_list.message:
[GUILT PATCH 2/5] guilt-guard: Assign guards to patches in series

guilt-guard will assign guards to a patch.  They work so that:

    * Patches with no guards are always pushed.

    * Patches with positive guards (i.e. +foo) are pushed *only if* the
      guard is selected.

    * Patches with negative guards (i.e. -foo) are pushed *unless* the
      guard is selected.

This also introduces a number of guard-related utility functions into
guilt.  get_guarded_series is used to get the list of patches that are
applicable given the current guard status.  It replaces get_series in
a later patch.

[jeffpc: small cleanups & bugfixes]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

commit_list.message:
[GUILT PATCH 4/5] get_series: return guarded patches only

This renames get_guarded_series to get_series, and introduces
get_full_series for when the full series is needed.  Many guilt
scripts Just Work with that change.  Those that don't are fixed up.

With this patch, guards are respected everywhere in guilt.

commit_list.message:
[PATCH] guilt: Add -h option to show man pages

git-sh-setup steals the -h|--h* argument and prints the usage message
of the command that calls it, which in this case is guilt.  Rather than
print the unhelpful guilt usage message, call guilt-help on the given
command instead.

[jsipek: Move the -h|--h* check up a little]
[jsipek: no need for dirname as guilt-help should be in the path]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>

[PATCH] guilt: Add -h option to show man pages

git-sh-setup steals the -h|--h* argument and prints the usage message
of the command that calls it, which in this case is guilt.  Rather than
print the unhelpful guilt usage message, call guilt-help on the given
command instead.

commit_list.message:
[GUILT PATCH 4/5] get_series: return guarded patches only

This renames get_guarded_series to get_series, and introduces
get_full_series for when the full series is needed.  Many guilt
scripts Just Work with that change.  Those that don't are fixed up.

With this patch, guards are respected everywhere in guilt.

Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

commit_list.message:
[GUILT PATCH 3/5] guilt-select: Select guards to apply when pushing patches

guilt-select chooses guards that alter which patches will be applied
with a guilt-push.  The selected guards are stored in
.git/patches/$branch/guards.

[jeffpc: small tweak of the usage string]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>
commit_list.repo_description: from http://repo.or.cz/w/guilt.git

commit_list.message:
[GUILT PATCH 2/5] guilt-guard: Assign guards to patches in series

guilt-guard will assign guards to a patch.  They work so that:

    * Patches with no guards are always pushed.

    * Patches with positive guards (i.e. +foo) are pushed *only if* the
      guard is selected.

    * Patches with negative guards (i.e. -foo) are pushed *unless* the
      guard is selected.

This also introduces a number of guard-related utility functions into
guilt.  get_guarded_series is used to get the list of patches that are
applicable given the current guard status.  It replaces get_series in
a later patch.

[jeffpc: small cleanups & bugfixes]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

commit_list.message:
Revert "Don't take ceiling of log2 of registers"

This reverts commit 754438eb16596941a2c85eba56a92d810094a69d.

Not taking the ceiling does the exact opposite of what the commit
message claims. By not taking the ceiling, many values will be
rounded down due to the cast to uint32: uint32(log2(64))=5. This
lead to some m values using only half the requested registers, and
subsequently errors close to 100%.

commit_list.message:
Remove huge m values from tests

Testing m values above 2^17 was asburd on such a small data set.
My words file only has 235886 elements.

Helpfully, this also highlights what is probably a bug since 7
of 13 m values are falling outside of their expected error range.
Five of the seven failing tests are off by at least an order of
magnitude.
commit_list.repo_description: hyperloglog counts things using the HyperLogLog algorithm to estimate cardinality

commit_list.message:
Don't take ceiling of log2 of registers

Taking the ceiling leads to more of the test values having an
error within expected range, but it's false hope because some of
the passing tests are being run twice because ceiling is rounding
values up.

[GUILT PATCH 5/5] Guards test suite

The guards patches touch a lot of guilt, so make sure they don't muck
anything up.

[jeffpc: port to new regression suite]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

[GUILT PATCH 4/5] get_series: return guarded patches only

This renames get_guarded_series to get_series, and introduces
get_full_series for when the full series is needed.  Many guilt
scripts Just Work with that change.  Those that don't are fixed up.

With this patch, guards are respected everywhere in guilt.

Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

[GUILT PATCH 3/5] guilt-select: Select guards to apply when pushing patches

guilt-select chooses guards that alter which patches will be applied
with a guilt-push.  The selected guards are stored in
.git/patches/$branch/guards.

[jeffpc: small tweak of the usage string]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

[GUILT PATCH 2/5] guilt-guard: Assign guards to patches in series

guilt-guard will assign guards to a patch.  They work so that:

    * Patches with no guards are always pushed.

    * Patches with positive guards (i.e. +foo) are pushed *only if* the
      guard is selected.

    * Patches with negative guards (i.e. -foo) are pushed *unless* the
      guard is selected.

This also introduces a number of guard-related utility functions into
guilt.  get_guarded_series is used to get the list of patches that are
applicable given the current guard status.  It replaces get_series in
a later patch.

[jeffpc: small cleanups & bugfixes]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

[GUILT PATCH 1/5] get_series: Remove comments from end of series lines

Also make sure that series_remove_patch and series_rename_patch do the
right thing if there are comments on the line.

[jeffpc: few tiny bugfixes]
Signed-off-by: Eric Lesh <eclesh@ucla.edu>
Signed-off-by: Josef 'Jeff' Sipek <jeffpc@josefsipek.net>

on the current branch.

repo_list.description: garble is a daemon that tests the resiliency of network clients
hyperloglog counts things using the HyperLogLog algorithm to estimate cardinality
recordio implements a file format for a sequence of records
slowtail tails a log file for a cron job or other intermittent process
sshbomb pretends to be sshd and sends random garbage to anyone who dares connect
welford implements a one-pass algorithm for computing mean and variance
